title: 104_hr3239
content:
The Act is titled the "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1996". It establishes the basis for investigation. The Act titled the "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1996" amends sections of title 28, United States Code, to specify the basis for investigation and subpoena power. The Act "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1996" amends title 28, United States Code to grant subpoena power and modify the authority of the Attorney General. The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1996" amends prosecutorial jurisdiction under title 28, United States Code, limiting it to alleged criminal law violations requested by the Attorney General. The independent counsel is granted authority to fully investigate and prosecute related criminal violations. The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1996" limits prosecutorial jurisdiction to alleged criminal law violations requested by the Attorney General. The independent counsel has the authority to fully investigate and prosecute related criminal violations, including perjury, obstruction of justice, destruction of evidence, and intimidation of witnesses. SEC. 6. ATTORNEYS' FEES. Amends Section 593(f) of title 28, United States Code to require courts to award attorneys' fees if an individual is acquitted of all charges, no conviction is obtained, or if a conviction is overturned on appeal. SEC. 7. ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPORT. Amends Section 594(l)(2) of title 28, United States Code to replace the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts with the Administrator of General Services. Requires the Administrator of General Services to provide office space for independent counsels within a Federal building unless cost-effective alternatives are available.

SEC. 8. AUTHORITIES AND DUTIES OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. SEC. 8. AUTHORITIES AND DUTIES OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Amends Section 594(f) of title 28, United States Code to include the release of information relating to criminal proceedings. Limits expenditures for independent counsel offices to a 2-year period unless specified in a later appropriations Act. SEC. 9. Treatment of classified information: Independent counsels must adhere to government procedures when handling classified information, failure to do so may result in removal. SEC. 10. Outside legal work: Independent counsels cannot engage in additional legal work during their term. SEC. 11. Elimination of reports. Section 594 of title 28, United States Code is amended by removing subparagraph (B) of paragraph (1), striking paragraph (2) after the first sentence, and eliminating paragraph (3). Section 595 is amended by removing paragraph (2) and adjusting the heading for paragraph (1). Section 596 is amended by adjusting paragraph (1) to remove subparagraph (B) and integrate the text of subparagraph (A) after "when". In section 596, paragraph (1) is adjusted to remove subparagraph (B) and integrate the text of subparagraph (A) after "when". The second sentence in paragraph (2) is also struck. SEC. 12. REMOVAL, TERMINATION, AND PERIODIC REAPPOINTMENT OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. The amendment allows for the removal of an independent counsel for failure to comply with Department of Justice policies. The court can terminate the office of an independent counsel if the investigation is completed or substantially done. The independent counsel can be removed if the investigation is completed or substantially done, allowing the Department of Justice to take over. Quarterly expenditures must be reported to specified committees without disclosing specific investigation details. The amendment made by this Act requires quarterly expenditure reporting without disclosing investigation details. Independent counsels must seek reappointment every 2 years. The court will reappoint the applicant if it determines they are still suitable for the office, otherwise, another qualified person will be appointed. If the court fails to take action within 90 days after the 2-year period, the office of independent counsel will terminate. SEC. 13 amends travel expense reimbursements for independent counsels and their appointees effective December 31, 1995. SEC. 14 states that the amendments do not apply to pending investigations before the independent counsel on the date of enactment.
